subject: RBA adds AUD 726mln to the banking system through repos vs. Prev. AUD 1.91bln
RBNZ buys NZD 400mln of government bonds in QE operations as targetted
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Fujifilm and Mitsubishi UFJ Lease and earnings; Mitsubishi Corp aircraft unit plans to cut half its workforce
content:
AUSTRALIA

Aristocrat Leisure (ALL AT) - Co. reached in principle agreement to settle Washington litigation for USD 31mln, while the Co. CEO noted expectations for the reopening of gaming venues by September. (Newswires)

CBA (CBA AT) - Co. partners with Menulog by offering customers cashback via CommBank rewards. (Newswires) Decmil Group (DCG AT) - Co. is expected to be suspended from trading as the company is still working to negotiate price on raising. (Newswires)

Estia Health (EHE AT) - Co. occupancy as of April 16th 91.7% vs. Prev. 93.8%, Co. will not provide future earnings guidance at this time. (Newswires)

Millenium Services Group (MIL AT) - Co. will become Advent Health through a reverse takeover offer. (Newswires)

Nine Entertainment (NEC AT) - Co. agrees to sell Stuff NZ to management for AUD 1 and will record a AUD 40mln-45mln negative item in FY results from the sale. (Newswires)

Ramsay Health Care (RHC AT) - Co. completes AUD 300mln share purchase plan. (Newswires)

Seven West Media (SWM AT) - Co. is in discussions with Beyond Pictures regarding offloading parts of its in-house production division. (Newswires)

Vicinity Centres (VCX AT) - Myer (MYR AT) and David Jones are thought to have re-negotiated new rental agreements with the Co. (Newswires)

Village Roadshow (VRL AT) - Co. shareholder Mittleman Brothers submitted a letter of concerns regarding the BGH takeover proposal. (Newswires)

Other News - US Secretary of State Pompeo suggested the US could simply disconnect from Australia if the Victoria state government’s agreed involvement in China’s Belt and Road initiative threatens telecommunication security. However, the US Ambassador to Australia later downplayed the comments and said they were in response to a "very remote hypothetical" and that the US has "absolute confidence" in Australia's ability to handle the issue. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Asics Corp (7936 JT) - Co. Q1 net loss JPY 243mln vs. Prev. profit JPY 4.4bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Casio Computer (6952 JT) - Co. FY net declined 20.5% Y/Y to JPY 17.6bln. (Newswires)

Fast Retailing (9983 JT) - Co. Uniqlo will begin selling face masks made from material used for its AIRism underwear that is cool and dries quickly. (Nikkei)

FujiFilm Holdings (4901 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 124.9bln vs. Prev. JPY 138.1bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Meiji Holdings (2269 JT) - Co. FY net loss JPY 14.1bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 280mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Corp (8058 JT) - Co.’s aircraft unit plans to cut half of its 1500 employees. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi UFJ Lease & Finance (8593 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 70.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 68.8bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Nissan (72031 JT) - Co. is reportedly to consider reducing more than 20K jobs worldwide which is around 14% of total staff. There were also reports that Co. is to seek additional USD 3bln of cost savings in mid-term plan and plans to shut a production line in Mississippi, while the Co., Renault and Mitsubishi Motors are to share their EV and PHV tech. (Newswires)

Takeda (4502 JT) - FDA approves Co.’s ALUNBRIG as a first-line treatment option for patients diagnosed with a rare and serious form of lung cancer. (Newswires)

State of Emergency - Japan is reportedly to lift the state of emergency declaration in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama and Hokkaido this Monday. (Nikkei)

Other News - Japanese government is considering compiling a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln which will consist of JPY 60tln for interest loan scheme for businesses and JPY 27tln for other financial support measures. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Lotte Shopping (023530 KS) - Co. is to sell 121 stores this year due to impact from the coronavirus pandemic. (Yonhap)

Other News - 9 out of 10 South Korea households were reported to have received emergency relief funds as part of efforts to address the coronavirus fallout. (Yonhap)

subject: China's Global Times tweets US is now unilaterally pushing decoupling with China and that a Chinese expert warned in the post-pandemic world, it might find it is decoupling with the rest of the world
RBA says excess cash at exchange settlement accounts at AUD 50.7bln vs. Prev.  AUD 53.5bln
New Zealand government was said to be mulling a national unemployment insurance program and to make temporary tax-free payments to those that lost their jobs due to the coronavirus
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR IS NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include: Light Calendar amid several Holiday Closures
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR IS NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include: Light Calendar amid several Holiday Closures
UK PM Johnson faces cabinet revolt for supporting senior adviser Cummings regarding lockdown breach
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

China’s Global Times stated that a research team led by Peking University is taking the lead by unsheathing neutralizing antibodies, which will likely lay the foundation for potent treatment against the coronavirus and that it would hopefully be available as early as this winter. (Twitter)

A vaccine developed in China for COVID-19 showed good results in a phase one clinical trial, according to a study released in the British Medical Journal showed on Friday. The vaccine was tested on humans and was said to develop immunity to SARS-COV-2 which is the virus behind COVID-19, while it was also deemed safe by the study and was described as "well-tolerated by humans." In other news, Hydroxycholoroquine test results published in The Lancet Journal across 96k patients, showed that there was no significant difference in COVID patients treated with the drug. (BreakingThe News/Twitter/Washington Post)

US NIH’s Fauci said that having looked at the Moderna (MRNA) data itself, it is really quite promising and that the data will be peer-reviewed. Fauci also commented that Gilead’s remdesivir study was statistically significant but the results were modest and suggested we can build on the remdesivir success. In related news, US will reportedly test experimental coronavirus vaccines in 100k people or more with the vaccine candidate from Oxford University may be tested side by side with Moderna's (MRNA) from July, while Johnson & Johnson, Merck and Sanofi vaccines could be added in summer. (Newswires)

US CDC reported coronavirus cases rose by 26,229 to a total of 1,622,114 and death toll rose by 1,047 to a total of 97,049. (Newswires)

US White House suspended travel to US for foreigners that have visited Brazil in past 14 days. (Newswires)

US state of Nevada is setting June 4th as re-opening date for casinos. (Newswires)

Japan is reportedly to lift the state of emergency declaration in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama and Hokkaido this Monday. (Nikkei)

 

ASIA-PAC

Chinese President Xi said the country’s economy will prove resilient in the long term and that it will stand on the right side of history amid the rise of protectionism. There were also separate comments from the NDRC that it expects domestic consumption to show signs of an improvement this month as new forms of consumption such as e-commerce are encouraged. (SCMP/Newswires)

China’s Global Times noted that Chinese experts predict the PBoC is highly likely to announce interest rate or RRR cuts in H2 to fuel an economic recovery due to blows stemming from the coronavirus pandemic and amid external uncertainties. (Global Times)

Chinese Foreign Ministry said that it will fight back if the US attempts to oppress them. In other news, a Chinese NPC official said as far as they know, the Hong Kong legislation is ready which will be passed in the next meeting of the NPC Standing Committee and could be passed into law after resolutions are voted for on May 28th. Furthermore, China Foreign Minister Wang said political virus is spreading in US along with the coronavirus and that US and China should look for ways to avoid a new cold war. (Newswires/Global Times)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said they are to fully co-operate with China to enact the National Security law as soon as possible and it was also reported that the Hong Kong government stated that China's Parliamentary decision on the national security law will not affect the rights and freedoms of Hong Kong citizens. (Newswires)

Anonymous organizers on social network groups on Telegram are now preparing for anti-government protests on June 4 and July 1, which would mark the so-called anniversaries of fighting the government. (Twitter)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US condemns China’s proposal to unilaterally and arbitrarily impose national security legislation on Hong Kong, while he added that China’s decision to bypass the HK legislature would be the ‘death knell’ for Hong Kong’s autonomy proposed under agreement. Pompeo also suggested the US could simply disconnect from Australia if the Victoria state government’s agreed involvement in China’s Belt and Road initiative threatens telecommunication security. However, US Ambassador to Australia later downplayed the comments and said they were in response to a "very remote hypothetical" and that the US has "absolute confidence" in Australia's ability to handle the issue. (Newswires)

US National Security Adviser O’Brien stated that the US government will likely impose economic sanctions on Hong Kong and China if China moves forward with national security law for Hong Kong. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department added 9 Chinese entities to its Entities List related to human rights abuses, while it was also reported that the US is to add 33 Chinese firms and institutions to an economic blacklist for actions including assisting with Chinese military activities. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK Conservative MPs have called for PM Johnson to speed up new legislation to make it more difficult for overseas SOEs, such as Chinese firms, to take over struggling UK companies. In other news, UK PM Johnson was reportedly planning to reduce Huawei’s involvement in UK 5G network. (FT/Telegraph)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson confirmed the UK will be in a position to move to step 2 of the plan and that early years and reception, year 1 and year 6 students will return to school on June 1st, while he added we are making good progress although the progress is provisional and that he is hearing signs of confidence regarding getting a vaccine this year. Furthermore, he said he has looked at the allegations regarding adviser Cummings who he said acted responsibly and legally, while he added that he understands his situation and thinks that many do but also noted he gets why people may feel confused and offended, which follows news that adviser Cummings was reported to Durham Police regarding breaking lockdown rules. (Newswires/Daily Mirror)

UK Chancellor Sunak authorised a bailout plan to save strategically important companies in which the government will acquire stakes in important companies experiencing acute financial difficulties, in which he widened the capacity of the Treasury to handle bespoke bailouts of viable companies that have exhausted all options. (FT/Newswires)

UK Home Secretary Patel said they are bringing in quarantine measures now to prevent a second wave and protect our gains. (Newswires)

UK government is said to be a in new disagreement with Brussels over delays in granting full diplomatic status to the EU’s representation in London. (FT)

BoE Deputy Governor Ramsden said on Friday that it is possible BoE will do more QE at the June meeting or subsequently, and that it is reasonable to have an open mind on negative rates but it is complex. Ramsden also stated there is plenty of headroom for conventional QE Gilt purchases and that UK economic upturn will be less sharp than downturn but also noted that indicators suggested Q2 GDP could fall slightly less than BoE's May scenario although it is still early days. (Newswires)

ECB Minutes stated the Governing Council was fully prepared to increase the size of the PEPP and adjust its composition by as much as necessary and for as long as needed. Minutes stated that the view was widely shared that the Governing Council’s monetary policy measures taken in March, and reinforced by decisions taken on the collateral framework in April, had provided forceful monetary accommodation, while it was cautioned that monetary policy was not able to address these problems on its own and that fiscal policy also needed to play an essential role. Furthermore, it was generally considered that of the three scenarios presented, the “mild” scenario was probably already too optimistic. (Newswires)

ECB's Chief Economist Lane said strategic challenges are especially acute under conditions of low inflation and low interest rates, since deviations from the medium-term inflation target are likely to be more persistent under such conditions. (Newswires)

  • UK Retail Sales (Apr) M/M-18.1% vs. Exp. -16.0% (Prev. -5.1%, Rev. -5.2%). (Newswires)
  • UK Retail Sales (Apr) Y/Y -22.6% vs. Exp. -22.2% (Prev. -5.8%)

 

FX

Fitch revised Iceland’s Outlook to Negative; Rating affirmed at A. (Newswires)

Turkey raised the tax on individual FX purchases to 1.0% from 0.2% and increased the withholding tax on banks’ commercial paper to 15% from 10% as it seeks to raise more funds to help address the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Baker Hughes (22/05): Total rigs -21 at 318; oil rigs -21 to 237; nat gas. unchanged at 79. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC+ members must remain committed to production cuts despite signs oil demand is starting to recover, while he added that there are tentative signs of recovery and we believe the worst is behind us according to Energy Intel. (Twitter)

US oil output is reported to be declining faster than anticipated with production by May 20th said to be down by almost 20% or 2.3mln bpd, while further declines are expected for the year. (FT)

Russian President Putin ordered a bailout of the nation’s oil industry. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US administration officials reportedly held discussions on Friday about the possibility of conducting a nuclear test which would be the first test explosion since 1992. This was after some officials asserted the China and Russia are conducting low yield nuclear tests, although the meeting concluded without any agreement. (Washington Post)

 

US

NY Fed cut Treasuries/TIPS purchases to USD 20bln (prev. 30bln) for the upcoming week. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

US stocks were flat/higher, having dipped in overnight trade after Beijing announced a security law which could allow it to bypass Hong Kong lawmakers to crackdown on dissent, and that has hit risk sentiment, sending ES stocks to lows just above 2,900. Desks have noted the resilience of US stocks while those in China, for instance, saw significant downside. From there, losses were gradually pared, helped along by some constructive remarks from NIH Director Fauci on Moderna’s (MRNA) hopeful COVID vaccine and in the latter part of the US day, stock futures made a run for the session high, which some attributed to news that the White House was to launch a huge testing initiative. and a late surge took the ES back to HOD. In terms of earnings, Nvidia (NVDA) saw a solid overall report, beating on top and bottom lines, authorizing a USD 7.24bln share repurchase programme while maintaining its dividend commitment. Deere (DE) beat on EPS and revenue but it expects global equipment sales to fall 30-40% this year. Alibaba (BABA) beat on EPS and revenue driven by an increase in online purchases during lockdown, while MAU’s rose to 846mln and annual active users rose to 726mln. SPX +0.2% at 2,955, NDX +0.4% at 9,414, DJIA -0.0% at 24,465.

The TPLEX bull-flattened to end the week as participants withdrew risk exposure ahead of the long weekend, rising US-China tensions over Hong Kong, and disappointing China growth/stimulus targets. By settlement, 2s unchanged at 0.17% and 30s -3bps at 1.37%. Yields made their lows overnight, alongside equity futures, on the tails of the lacklustre China deficit target and lack of concrete GDP target. However, as the US session came into the horizon, equity futures and yields began to climb back higher finding support from Fauci comments and after the US equity open, yields traded rangebound through till settlement. T-Note futures (M0) settled 3 ticks higher at 139-05.

subject: Japanese government is considering compiling a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln which will consist of JPY 60tln for interest loan scheme for businesses and JPY 27tln for other financial support measures
